title: How to Make a Red Velvet Poke Cake

steps.headline: Mix the butter and sugar together.
steps.description: Mix ½ cup (113 grams) of butter with 1 ½ cups (300 grams) of sugar until it is light and fluffy. You can either using a mixing spoon or an electric stand mixer to do this faster. If you are trying to cut down on your butter usage, you can use vegetable or canola oil.

steps.headline: Add two eggs, vanilla, and buttermilk to the mixture.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (236 milliliters) of buttermilk to your butter and sugar mixture. Mix in one egg at a time and beat the mixture until the eggs are incorporated into the mix. Continue to do this until there are no more lumps. Once you're done, put 2 teaspoons (10 milliliters) of vanilla into the mix.

steps.headline: Mix cocoa powder and food coloring in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Create a paste out of the cocoa powder and food coloring by mixing it together with a fork. Use 3 tablespoons (22 grams) of cocoa powder and 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of red food coloring. Once the paste is adequately mixed, add it to your egg and milk mixture. The cocoa will impart hints of chocolate in your cake and the food coloring will give it it's signature color. McCormick makes a red food dye that you can find in many grocery stores.

steps.headline: Add baking soda and flour to the mixture.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon (5 grams) of baking soda and 2 ½ cups (320 grams) of all-purpose flour to your liquid mixture. Pour the baking soda and flour to the mixture slowly, a little at a time. Mix the cake batter between pours of the flour and baking soda. Once your baking soda and flour is added to the wet mixture, you'll have finished making your red velvet batter.

steps.headline: Combine the butter and cream cheese.
steps.description: Add 3 ounces (85.04 grams) of butter and 12 ounces (340.19 grams) of cream cheese to an electric mixer or a bowl and combine them. Continue to mix the butter and cream cheese until it's well blended. When using an electric mixer, use the paddle attachment. If you don't have an electric device you can use a hand beater or fork.

steps.headline: Add the vanilla and powdered sugar.
steps.description: Add 1 1/2 teaspoons (7.393 milliliters) of vanilla extract to a bowl. Slowly incorporate the sugar into the mix by pouring four ounces of sugar in at a time. Continue to do this until you've mixed in all the sugar. The sugar will thicken the frosting and make it sweeter. Add more sugar to make your icing thicker. You can elevate your frosting by adding flaked coconut, cocoa powder and a pinch of salt, or blueberry syrup.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the icing.
steps.description: Before you use your icing, it should be refrigerated for five to ten minutes so that it can set. If your frosting is not the consistency you desire, consider using a thicker or lighter cream cheese next time. You can make your icing in advance if you don't want to make the cake all at once.

steps.headline: Heat your oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and grease your baking pan.
steps.description: Your cake needs to be thick enough to absorb the condensed milk, so use a deep pan. Grease the bottom of your pan with some melted butter or a cooking spray. It's important to wait till your oven is preheated or your cake may be underdone. A 9×13-inch baking pan is a good size to use.

steps.headline: Pour your red velvet cake mixture into the baking pan.
steps.description: Take the red velvet cake mix that you made and carefully pour it into the baking pan. Let the pan fill up with the mix before leveling the surface of the cake with a spatula. Once you've used all the batter, you can put it in your preheated oven.

steps.headline: Bake the cake for 25 minutes.
steps.description: Bake the cake until it's done. You can test the readiness of your cake by inserting a toothpick into it. If you can pull the toothpick out clean, it means that inside of your red velvet cake is done. Do not leave your cake in for more than 25 minutes or it may overcook.

steps.headline: Cool the cake for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Use oven mitts or oven rags to carefully take your cake out of the oven. Letting it sit for 20 minutes helps the center solidify.

steps.headline: Poke holes across the top of the cake.
steps.description: Using the end of a wooden spoon, create holes across the surface of the cake. Make sure to space the holes out evenly. Space the holes two to three inches apart from one other. Go over the entirety of the cake until there are four or five rows of holes with four holes in each row.

steps.headline: Pour condensed milk over the top of the cake.
steps.description: Add the condensed milk over the top of the cake so that it gets poured into the holes that you made. You can pour the milk directly from the can. This will add sweetness and smoothness to your red velvet cake. Spread the milk over the surface with a spatula so that there is an equal distribution.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the cake for two hours.
steps.description: Cover your cake with a clear plastic wrap or tin foil and place it in the refrigerator. The cold will help the condensed milk harden and will make it easier for you to apply your icing to the cake. If you haven't made the frosting yet, this is an excellent time to do it.

steps.headline: Spread your icing over the surface of the cake.
steps.description: Take your cake out of the refrigerator and use a spatula to spread your cream cheese icing over the top of the cake. Add as much or as little icing as you want. Once the icing is on the cake, it's ready to be eaten. Cut pieces of the cake and serve. Do not try to spread your icing over a hot cake. Allow the cake to cool, or your icing will liquefy.

text: Mixing the Batter Mix the butter and sugar together. Mix ½ cup (113 grams) of butter with 1 ½ cups (300 grams) of sugar until it is light and fluffy. You can either using a mixing spoon or an electric stand mixer to do this faster. If you are trying to cut down on your butter usage, you can use vegetable or canola oil. Add two eggs, vanilla, and buttermilk to the mixture. Add 1 cup (236 milliliters) of buttermilk to your butter and sugar mixture. Mix in one egg at a time and beat the mixture until the eggs are incorporated into the mix. Continue to do this until there are no more lumps. Once you're done, put 2 teaspoons (10 milliliters) of vanilla into the mix. Mix cocoa powder and food coloring in a separate bowl. Create a paste out of the cocoa powder and food coloring by mixing it together with a fork. Use 3 tablespoons (22 grams) of cocoa powder and 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of red food coloring. Once the paste is adequately mixed, add it to your egg and milk mixture. The cocoa will impart hints of chocolate in your cake and the food coloring will give it it's signature color. McCormick makes a red food dye that you can find in many grocery stores. Add baking soda and flour to the mixture. Add 1 teaspoon (5 grams) of baking soda and 2 ½ cups (320 grams) of all-purpose flour to your liquid mixture. Pour the baking soda and flour to the mixture slowly, a little at a time. Mix the cake batter between pours of the flour and baking soda. Once your baking soda and flour is added to the wet mixture, you'll have finished making your red velvet batter. Making the Icing Combine the butter and cream cheese. Add 3 ounces (85.04 grams) of butter and 12 ounces (340.19 grams) of cream cheese to an electric mixer or a bowl and combine them. Continue to mix the butter and cream cheese until it's well blended. When using an electric mixer, use the paddle attachment. If you don't have an electric device you can use a hand beater or fork. Add the vanilla and powdered sugar. Add 1 1/2 teaspoons (7.393 milliliters) of vanilla extract to a bowl. Slowly incorporate the sugar into the mix by pouring four ounces of sugar in at a time. Continue to do this until you've mixed in all the sugar. The sugar will thicken the frosting and make it sweeter. Add more sugar to make your icing thicker. You can elevate your frosting by adding flaked coconut, cocoa powder and a pinch of salt, or blueberry syrup. Refrigerate the icing. Before you use your icing, it should be refrigerated for five to ten minutes so that it can set. If your frosting is not the consistency you desire, consider using a thicker or lighter cream cheese next time. You can make your icing in advance if you don't want to make the cake all at once. Baking the Cake Heat your oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and grease your baking pan. Your cake needs to be thick enough to absorb the condensed milk, so use a deep pan. Grease the bottom of your pan with some melted butter or a cooking spray. It's important to wait till your oven is preheated or your cake may be underdone. A 9×13-inch baking pan is a good size to use. Pour your red velvet cake mixture into the baking pan. Take the red velvet cake mix that you made and carefully pour it into the baking pan. Let the pan fill up with the mix before leveling the surface of the cake with a spatula. Once you've used all the batter, you can put it in your preheated oven. Bake the cake for 25 minutes. Bake the cake until it's done. You can test the readiness of your cake by inserting a toothpick into it. If you can pull the toothpick out clean, it means that inside of your red velvet cake is done. Do not leave your cake in for more than 25 minutes or it may overcook. Cool the cake for 20 minutes. Use oven mitts or oven rags to carefully take your cake out of the oven. Letting it sit for 20 minutes helps the center solidify. Poke holes across the top of the cake. Using the end of a wooden spoon, create holes across the surface of the cake. Make sure to space the holes out evenly. Space the holes two to three inches apart from one other. Go over the entirety of the cake until there are four or five rows of holes with four holes in each row. Pour condensed milk over the top of the cake. Add the condensed milk over the top of the cake so that it gets poured into the holes that you made. You can pour the milk directly from the can. This will add sweetness and smoothness to your red velvet cake. Spread the milk over the surface with a spatula so that there is an equal distribution. Refrigerate the cake for two hours. Cover your cake with a clear plastic wrap or tin foil and place it in the refrigerator. The cold will help the condensed milk harden and will make it easier for you to apply your icing to the cake. If you haven't made the frosting yet, this is an excellent time to do it. Spread your icing over the surface of the cake. Take your cake out of the refrigerator and use a spatula to spread your cream cheese icing over the top of the cake. Add as much or as little icing as you want. Once the icing is on the cake, it's ready to be eaten. Cut pieces of the cake and serve. Do not try to spread your icing over a hot cake. Allow the cake to cool, or your icing will liquefy. Finished!
